There is a 0 correlation historically b/t the S&P 500 & Bitcoin. This should not be a surprise. There is no fundamental reason to expect them to move in the same direction on a consistent basis.  But 0 correlation does not mean that they won't move together or inversely at times.

It could re-test the lows, break the lows, or it could continue to run. When you study the end of bear markets you find a re-test is not a requirement by any means. In March 2009, there was never a re-test, and S&P rallied straight up 43% before its first meaningful pullback...
Would that speed be unprecedented following a 20% decline? No. In 1998, the S&P bottomed on October 8 after a 22% decline, then rallied 29% to new highs by November 24. $SPX
If it continued at this pace S&P would hit new highs before the end of February.

For the S&P 500 to finish lower in 2018 it would take a decline from here of at least 4.9%. In the past 90 years, we've seen a decline of that magnitude in December only 3 times: 1930 (-6.4%), 1931 (-14.5%), and 2002 (-5.9%).

When Bitcoin fell 85% from Dec 2013 to Jan 2015 the S&P 500 was up 12%. Just like Gold, a 0 correlation does not imply that they won't move together at times - they will, both up and down. But a decline in Bitcoin is not predictive of a decline in stocks and vice versa.

Going back to 2010, there is a 0 correlation between S&P 500 and Bitcoin. This should not be a surprise. There is no fundamental reason to expect them to move in the same direction on a consistent basis.
I'm often asked what impact the Bitcoin sell-off will have on stocks. Returns since Bitcoin Peak in December 2017... S&P 500: +2.4% Bitcoin: -58.8%
